description: Originally Trinidad English, an alteration of kaiso, perhaps ultimately of African origin; Allsopp 1996 suggests Ibibio ka iso (“come on”), used to urge dancers on. The spelling reflects a later folk-etymological assimilation with the mythological name Calypso.

nouns.description: calypso (countable and uncountable, plural calypsos or calypsoes)

entries.meaning: A style of Caribbean music that originated in Trinidad and Tobago during the early to the mid-19th century and spread to the rest of the Caribbean Antilles and Venezuela by the mid-20th century. Its rhythms can be traced back to West African Kaiso and the arrival of French planters and their slaves from the French Antilles in the 18th century.
examples:
'How you does live, Mr. Wordsworth?' I asked him one day.
He said, 'You mean how I get money?'When I nodded, he laughed in a crooked way.He said, 'I sing calypsoes in the calypso season.''And that last you the rest of the year?''It is enough.'

verbs.description: calypso (third-person singular simple present calypsos, present participle calypsoing, simple past and past participle calypsoed)

description: From Latin, itself from Ancient Greek Καλυψώ (Kalupsṓ, “name of a sea nymph”)

nouns.description: calypso (countable and uncountable, plural calypsos or calypsoes)

entries.meaning: A bulbous bog orchid of the genus Calypso, Calypso bulbosa
